titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Office of the Vice President, Office Files of David Bell
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Office of the Vice President, Office Files of David Bell FA624
titlestmt.author: Arranged and described by Claire McCurdy, Ford Foundation Archives, July 1984

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-03-10 00:00:25 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Office of the Vice President, Office Files of David Bell
did.abstract:
The papers of David Bell, Vice President of the Ford Foundation's International Division from 1966 to 1981, document his activities at the Ford Foundation and those of the International Division during this period. They were sent to the Foundation's Archives in July 1981 by Alice Maloney, who served as Secretary and Executive Assistant to Mr. Bell for the duration of his tenure.
The papers consist primarily of correspondence, memoranda, and Bell's rough notes summarizing meetings and conferences attended. They are divided into six series. The series' order is based on substance and size. Arrangement of files within a series corresponds closely to the original order established by Ms. Maloney.
The papers are particularly rich in the following areas:
• the activities of the International Division: the Office of the Vice President and the overseas field offices (Series I) • the annual meetings of the Board of Trustees and its subcommittees (Series II) • the activities of the international agricultural center system, including the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research (Series IV) • the Foundation's Population Program (Series V)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: David E. Bell, Executive Vice President of the Ford Foundation's International Division, was a member of the Foundation staff from June 1966 until his retirement in August 1981. During this period, he held the following positions:
• March 1969, Executive Vice President, International Division • June 1966, Vice President, International Division

David Bell was born on January 20, 1919. He received his B.A. degree with highest honors from Pomona College of Claremont, California, in 1939, and was elected Phi Beta Kappa. In 1941, he earned an M.A. in Economics from Harvard University.
Prior to Bell's career with the Ford Foundation, he held the following positions:

• 1942, Budget Examiner, U.S. Bureau of the Budget • 1945-51, Assistant to the Chief, Fiscal Division, The White House • 1951-53, Administrative Assistant to the President, The White House • 1954-57, Field Supervi sor, Pakistan Planning Board Project, IIE - Harvard University, Pakistan • 1957-60, Lecturer, Economics; Secretary, Graduate School of Public Administration, Harvard University • 1961-62, Director, U.S. Bureau of the Budget • 1962-66, Administrator, Agency for International Development
After his retirement from the Foundation, Mr. Bell joined the Faculty of the Harvard University School of Public Health.
Mr. Bell's personal papers have been donated to the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library. Other papers are at the Harry Truman Presidential Library.

archdesc.scopecontent:
Scope and Contents David Bell's papers document his Foundation activities from 1966 to 1981, particularly in the following areas:
• the International Division: the Office of the Vice President and the overseas field offices; • the Board of Trustees and its subcommittees; • the International Agricultural Center system, including the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research and the International Food Policy Research Institute; • the Foundation's Population Program.
They reflect Bell's involvement with policy development and implementation, program and budget planning and administration, administrative procedures, and meetings and conferences for the following programs in the International Division: Office of the Vice President (OVP), Asia and the Pacific (A&P), Europe and International Affairs (EIA), Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC), and Middle East and Africa (MEA).
The papers contain materials on a review (the Overseas Development Self-Study, or "0peration Janus", initiated by F. Champion Ward) and reorganization of the Foundation's international activities into programs based upon geographical areas. There is also material on the planning and implementation of the 1979-1980 Program Reviews in preparation for the second Foundation-wide program reorganization.
For Ford Foundation International Division meetings and conferences from 1966 to 1979, the papers contain lists of participants, agenda, notes for discussion, and notes or memoranda summarizing the proceedings. There is also material on the planning and administration of special programs such as the International Division Programs for Women for the years 1975 to 1980. Other topics of special interest include Bell's meetings with the Chinese delegation of December 1980 and the Ford Foundation Pakistan Reviews of 1969 and 1979.
Bell maintained a flow of correspondence with Foundation colleagues and Trustees, Heads of State, ex-USAID colleagues, and grantee and other philanthropic organizations. Of special interest is the correspondence between Bell and such individuals as McGeorge Bundy, Henry Ford II, Alexander Heard, Soedjatmoko, and Patricia Ward, and such organizations as the Council on Foreign Relations, the Overseas Development Council, and several agencies of the United Nations.
For the meetings of the Ford Foundation Board of Trustees and its International, Executive, Finance, and Communications Committees for the years 1966 to 1980, the papers contain lists of participants, agenda, notes for discussion, and notes and/or memoranda summarizing the discussions. Of particular interest: the Special Board Review Meetings of 1976, and the Board of Trustees Meeting in India (1978).
During Bell's tenure, the Foundation was instrumental in the development of eight international centers for agricultural research. The papers are rich in material on five of the eight centers: the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI), the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA), the Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical (CIAT), the International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT), and the International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics (ICRISAT). The papers document the centers' growth, their program planning and administration, and meetings and conferences from 1966 to 1981. There are lists of participants, agenda, notes for discussion, and Bell's notes summarizing the proceedings.
Most of the agricultural center material is related to: the activities of the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research (CGIAR) and its Task Force on International Assistance for National Agricultural Research (ISNAR) for the years 1971 to 1976; the annual meetings of the International Centers Week for the years 1970 to 1979; the Ford and Rockefeller (Bellagio) Meetings on Agriculture and Development (1969-1970, 1975); and the activities of the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) for the years 1974 to 1979, as it sought and gained entry into the CGIAR system. Other topics of interest include the respective roles of CGIAR and the United Nations and Agricultural Organization (FAO) in agricultural development (1978), and the review of donor support to CGIAR and the centers (1979-1980).
The Population Program expanded considerably during Bell's tenure. The papers contain material on program planning, administration, and evaluation for this period. For the Ford and Rockefeller (Bellagio) Conferences on Population and Development from 1968 to 1979, the papers contain lists of participants, agenda, notes for discussion, and notes summarizing the proceedings. There is also material on the collaborative discussions with the Rockefeller Foundation on Roy O. Greep and Marjorie Koblinsky's "Reproduction and Human Welfare: A Challenge to Research" (1976); the subsequent meetings with Joseph Califano to discuss alternatives to abortion (1977); and a review of Ford Foundation field staff comment on Sol Chafkin's Health/Nutrition/Population (H/N/P) proposal to the Foundati on (1978-1981).
Finally, Bell retained material on selected Foundation procedures, divisions and offices of the Foundation other than the OVP/ID, selected subject areas in which grants were made, and selected surveys and studies. Of particular interest is the material on the Tax Reform Act of 1969 and the ID follow-up; and the Task Forces on Finance, Procedures, and FAPs (Foundation-Administered Projects).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers of David Bell are divided into six series:
I. International Division Files
II. General Correspondence Files
III. Trustee Meeting Files
IV. Agriculture Files
V. Population Files
VI. Subject Files

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Some groups of papers have been removed and placed with the appropriate collections within the Ford Foundation Archives:

• Files of F. F. Hill/F. Champion Ward/W. P. Gormbley • International Division Budget Papers • International Division Program Review Papers • Ford Foundation Conference Papers • Minutes and Dockets of Trustee Meetings • Staff and consultant reports and publications.

Their locations have been noted on cross-reference sheets. A list of titles of reports removed from the papers is appended to this register. Papers not related to Ford Foundation activities have been pulled and discarded.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details.
Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical

p.emph: Segment One: International Activities of the Ford Foundation: An Overview

bioghist.p: The Foundation's aspiration to become a national and international philanthropy for the advancement of human welfare was first formally expressed in the seminal 1949 report of the Gaither Study Committee, Report of the Study for the Ford Foundation on Policy and Program (RAC Library, call letters 361.7 GAI ), which was commissioned by the Board of Trustees to chart the Foundation's future. Foundation Trustees launched Ford's international grantmaking activities in 1950 when they approved the committee's report and its embrace of peace, democracy, and freedom. Since then, the Foundation has tackled these goals using a variety of strategies and responding to changing contexts, from the Cold War to the 1989 fall of the Berlin Wall and beyond.

Toward the Foundation's aspirational goal, "the establishment of peace", its international activities have comprised a wide range of conceptual approaches and focus areas. These include international affairs, international studies, international understanding, arms control and disarmament, international law, international economic concerns, and overseas development in nearly every region of the world. Three distinct periods emerge for the international grantmaking defined by external contextual changes and internal changes in Foundation leadership and structures: the expansion era of 1950-1965; the transition and restructuring years of 1966-1988; and the post-1989 shift away from Cold War dichotomies. During each of the distinct historical periods the consistent objectives were: 1) to ensure freedom and democracy in developed countries; 2) to foster education and international understanding in all countries; and 3) to contribute to the social, economic, and political development of less developed countries.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical

p.emph: Segment 3. Period Sketch - Transition and Restructuring 1966-1988

bioghist.p: In the 1960s, the Ford Foundation Trustees began to rethink the role of the Foundation in the context of the era's dramatic political and cultural changes. For instance, the passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act created a domestic policy context in which the Foundation could more deeply engage with issues of rights and social justice. Events overseas starting in the late 1960s would extend the rights agenda to international affairs and development operations at the Foundation -- all advanced by the leadership of McGeorge Bundy (president, 1966-1979).

McGeorge Bundy was appointed president in 1966, following a significant career in national security and academic administration. During World War II, he worked with the Army's intelligence division, and in the early post-war years was a political analyst at the Council on Foreign Relations. Even without a postgraduate degree, at the age of thirty -four he became dean of the Faculty of Arts and Science at Harvard University. In 1961, President Kennedy appointed Bundy to be Special Assistant to the President for National Security - a position he held for five years under both Kennedy and Johnson. Those significant years saw the Bay of Pigs invasion, the Cuban Missile Crisis, and the beginnings of the Vietnam War.

When Bundy arrived at the Foundation, he initiated a restructuring that modeled government departments rather than the academic ones President Henry Heald had established in the 1950s. At the same time, he had to contend with serious financial constraints due to Ford's overspending in the prior periods and to economic downturns in the global economy. The Board of Trustees mandated an annual spending of over $100 million.

These economic constraints meant that Foundation programs had to be more selective across the range of its programs. Nonetheless, international activities remained prominent with the new president and trustees. President Bundy and key trustees such Eugene Black (1960-1968, former head of the World Bank) and Robert S. McNamara (1968-1986, former U.S. Secretary of Defense and then head of the World Bank, 1968-1981) reflected a commitment to the international activities. Bundy also added to the board in 1972 the first trustee from a developing country, the Indonesian activist and scholar, Dr. Soedjakmoto, the former Ambassador to the United States from his country and then Special Adviser on Social and Cultural Affairs to the Chairman of Indonesia's National Development Planning Agency.

To create economies of scale, Bundy unified US-based international and overseas activities under one division: the International Division (using the name for the first time). That division comprised Resources for Development (area studies, languages, and exchanges), Population, International Relations, Planning and Evaluation, and the country programs. David Bell, an economist and the first administrator of the US Agency for International Development (1962-1966), was named vice president and served in that capacity until the end of Bundy presidency.

In 1966, Bundy terminated the long-standing internationally oriented but domestically based International Training and Research Program. Several large domestic programs -- including support of centers of international studies - were phased out in the 1970s. Instead, Ford launched under its international affairs efforts a focused but robust program in security and arms control. Over Bundy's tenure, the overseas offices were reduced from twenty in 1966 to twelve in 1979, when he retired.

The Foundation increasingly turned its attention to different set of international issues including human rights and working in repressive societies, such as South Africa. The military coups in Latin America during the late 1960s and early 1970s led the Foundation to initiate in 1976 a human rights program housed in Vice President Bell's office.

In 1979, Franklin Thomas was named president of the Ford Foundation (1979-1996). In contrast to Bundy's international and defense policy background, Franklin Thomas brought to the Ford Foundation his experience in law, housing, and community development. Prior to joining the Foundation, Thomas, a lawyer, was a Foundation trustee. He chaired the Rockefeller Foundation-funded Study Commission on U.S. Policy towards South Africa and led the Ford-funded Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation in New York from its beginning in 1966 until he left in 1979. Earlier, he had been deputy police commissioner of NYC.

In the first decade of Thomas' tenure, the international work was still framed using the post-war East-West dichotomy. Several trustees brought to the board active engagement in international issues: Donald F. McHenry (trustee over the period 1981-1993) had served as ambassador to the U.N. and was active in the anti-apartheid movement; and General Olusegun Obasanjo (trustee over the period 1987-1999) had been Nigerian head of state from 1976-1979, and was then president of the African leadership Forum. Along with McNamara and Soedjakmoto, Rodrigo Botero, an internationally renowned economist from Colombia and former Colombian Minister of Finance and Credit from 1974 to1976, remained on the board over the period 1978-1989.

During the early years of the Thomas presidency, the scope and strategies of the Foundation's activities were also influenced by economic and global pressures, leading to reduced assets and further financial stringencies. Thomas' board-mandated reductions resulted, for example, the firing of twenty senior staff at the same time. To achieve more effective and efficient programs, Thomas had a vision of Ford as one foundation, linking the domestic and overseas activities under new program themes: Urban Poverty, Rural Poverty and Resources, Human Rights and Social Justice, Governance and Public Policy, Education and Culture, and International Affairs.

The restructured Foundation comprised two programmatic divisions led by vice presidents: U.S. and International Affairs Programs (USIAP) headed by Susan Berresford; and Developing Countries Program (DCP), headed by William Carmichael. Berresford had been at the Foundation since 1970, coming from the U.S. Manpower Career Development Agency. She served in the National Affairs area, first as program assistant and then program officer (1972-1980), becoming head of women's programs in 1980. The main international efforts under USIAP were housed in Rural Poverty and Resources, Human Rights and Governance, and International Affairs. The other programs - Urban Poverty, Education and Culture, and Program-Related Investments - also addressed a scattering of international issues related to their main themes.

Carmichael had joined the Foundation in 1968 as Representative in Brazil. In July 1971, he was named Head of the Office of Latin America and the Caribbean, and in September of 1977, he became Head of the Middle East and Africa Office. The DCP program was responsible for all the Field Offices: Andean and the Southern Cone, Brazil, Mexico and Central America, Bangladesh, India, Southeast Asia, West Africa, Eastern and Southern Africa, and Middle East and North Africa.

When the Foundation initiated a Human Rights and Governance program (HR&G) in 1981, it was the first instance of a Ford program explicitly entitled "human rights," despite the fact that human rights grantmaking that had started officially in 1976. International Affairs remained separate from HR&G. In 1987, however, the Board conceptually linked three programs, creating a Trustee committee called Human Rights, Governance, and International Affairs, which existed until 1992. Operationally, however, the programs relating to these fields did not often work together.

International governance remained a commitment under Thomas. The Foundation, for example, had a long-established relationship with the United Nations: from 1951 until 1988, the United Nations received ninety grants from the Foundation (it received another 198 over the period 1989-2009).

In these early years of the Thomas presidency, dramatic changes were occurring in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Under President Mikhail Gorbachev's leadership since 1985, the USSR was opening up to the international community, the rule of law in society was taking prominence there, and press freedoms were spreading. The foundation developed new programs in the region, drawing on the $60 million already spent to promote human rights and free expression and increase Western understanding of developments there.

Given the continuing economic constraints facing the Foundation and rising debt in developing countries, the Foundation shifted support under DCP to smaller scale community-based initiatives in the field offices. Thomas was also charged by the Board to increase the diversity of grantees, especially to favor populations "most affected" by the problems of concern to the Ford Foundation. The Foundation built on earlier efforts and sharpened its focus on women's issues throughout the world, including shifting the focus of the population program to women' reproductive health and child survival.

In the 1980s, Carmichael and others, with strong support from Thomas and the board, continued the 1970s' support of South African grantees for training large numbers of black lawyers and litigating sensitive cases in the South African legal system. Recognizing the multifaceted nature of discrimination in South Africa, the Foundation not only advanced the rule of law, but also strengthened civic organizations, women's groups, and educational institutions. Further, it supported a number of activist organizations in the United States that were energetically advocating US governmental sanctions against South Africa and for private disinvestment. The Foundation also played a role in shaping US policy on apartheid through the role Thomas played from 1985 to 1987 chairing the US Secretary of State's Advisory Committee on South Africa.

The Foundation's overseas staff also sought to improve the economic situation in poor, marginalized communities through targeted loan programs particularly to women head of households, beginning with the innovative work in Bangladesh of Professor Mohammed Yunus, the founder of the Grameen Bank. The results led the way to establish the field of microfinance with the aim of empowering women living in poverty conditions, such as through a microfinance network in Latin America starting 1980 and a global lending program for women starting in 1987.

Thomas encouraged staff to share results at worldwide meetings. During those meetings, Ford staff in the country offices and in New York tried to follow the mandate to work as "one foundation." The persistent challenge toward meeting that goal, however, was that initiatives emerging from the New York-based programs, or indeed any program developed in one country, were not always adaptable, relevant or acceptable in other countries or regions. It remained a challenge to develop a unified program, despite the commitment at the highest level of foundation leadership.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical

p.emph: Segment 3. Period Summary - Transition and Restructuring 1966-1988

bioghist.p: During this era, the Foundation's earlier interest in business and the economy evolved into a commitment to improving conditions for people living on the margins of society. The Ford Foundation promoted advancements in women's rights around the globe and introduced micro-lending into grantmaking. At the same time, the economic issues that were shaping program strategies also affected the Foundation's assets. Severe cuts resulted in a significant restructuring of country programs and reduced budgets across all programs.

Even with the cuts in country offices, in the 1970s Ford grantees in developing countries received approximately 80% of the International Division budget. The remaining fifth went to Population, Development Studies, and International Affairs. Although representing a much smaller piece, the International Security and Arms Control program from 1973 was the Foundation's most concerted effort to make meaningful inroads in disarmament and nuclear issues - those challenges most directly linked to the Foundation's historic concern for peace. By 1979, the Ford Foundation was the biggest funder of arms control as a field, both in the U.S. and overseas.

c.scopecontent: Scope and ContentsSeries I, International Division Files (1966-1981), is the most extensive. It contains material on the activities of the Office of the Vice President (OVP), International Division; its re-organization in 1966, and its administrative policies. There is extensive material on the program planning and administration of the Division's overseas field offices in the four program areas in effect at that time: A&P, EIA, LAC, and MEA (Asia & Pacific, Europe and International Affairs, Latin America and the Caribbean, and Middle East and Africa). The substantial Budget sub-series includes material on the Program and Budget Reviews of 1979 and 1980. There are also files on the annual meetings and conferences of the International Division, and on the Overseas Development Self-Study of 1966-1967 ("0peration Janus").

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is divided into the following five sub-series:
A. Office of the Vice President Files (1 box)
B. Field Office Files (4 boxes)
C. International Division Meetings and Conference Files (2 boxes)
D. International Division Budget Files (4 boxes)
E. Overseas Division Self-Study Files (0.5 boxes)

did.unittitle: Office of the Vice President Files

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is further divided into two sections. The first section consists of general material on the organization of the International Division. It is arranged chronologically. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

The second section consists of files on International Division administration and special programs. It is arranged alphabetically by folder title. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

did.unittitle: ID Organization - Europe and Far East
Office of the Vice President/Int'l Division (General)
ID - Discretionary Awards, Travel and Study

c.arrangement: ArrangementThis sub-series is further divided into four sections: the Asia & Pacific (A&P), Europe and International Affairs (EIA), Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC), and Middle East and Africa (MEA) programs of the International Division. Within each section, the folders are arranged alphabetically, and within each folder, the material is arranged in reverse chronological order.

ID/MEA - Congo and other West Africa
ID/MEA - Lebanon and Beirut Office - Regional
International Division Meetings and Conference Files

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is further divided into two sections: International Division divisional meetings and conferences, and International Division meetings and conferences on selected subjects. Within each section, the folders are arranged chronologically, and within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

did.unittitle: ID Conference - Nairobi, June 1968 - Summary Notes

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is further divided into the following sections: general files on the ID Budget, ID Budget Program Review files, and Bell's notes on selected subjects re: ID Budget/Program Reviews. Within each section, the folders are arranged chronologically. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

did.unittitle: International Division Budget - Planning and Evaluation Agenda - General
International Division Budget - Planning and Evaluation Agenda - ID Responses
International Division Budget Balance of Payments
International Division Budget Grant Status Reports - Backlog
International Division Program Reviews - Commitment Status, Year-End Balance of Appropriations

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Th is sub-series is arranged according to the order in which it was originally received and consists of material on the OD Self-Study - "0peration Janus". Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

did.unittitle: OD Self-Study - ID Meeting/Beirut Jan. 1967 - General
OD Self-Study - ID Meeting/Beirut Jan. 1967 - Agenda and Summary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Correspondence (1966-1980), contains correspondence generated by Mr. Bell during his years at the Foundation. Correspondents include Foundation colleagues and Trustees, Heads of State, ex-USAID colleagues, and grantee and other philanthropic organizations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is divided into the following two sub-series:
A. Alphabetical Files (3 boxes)
B. Chronological Files (7 boxes)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files consist of Bell's selected incoming and outgoing correspondence with Ford Foundation trustees and colleagues, grantee and membership organizations, and other donor organizations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These files are arranged alphabetically. Within each folder, correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

did.unittitle: CFR - Discussion Group on Foreign Aid Policy
CFR - Discussion Group on Foreign Aid Policy
CFR - Special Discussion Group: Vietnam's Post-Conflict Problems
CFR - Latin American Advisory Group (Nelson Rockefeller)
CFR - Discussion Group on Multilateral Economic Development
CFR - Study Group on American Aid Policy
CFR - Study Group on Transfer Of Technology
UN - Intergovt. - World Bank - Employment Meeting, Feb. 1975
UN University - Human & Social Development Meeting, Tokyo, November 1975
UN University Meeting, Nov. 1975 - Background Papers
United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files consist of Bell's routine outgoing correspondence ("chrons") with Ford Foundation trustees and colleagues, grantee and membership organizations, other donor organizations, heads of state, and ex-USAID colleagues.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These files are arranged chronologically. Within each year, they are arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Johnson, A. A. - Johnson, H. G.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Trustee Meeting Files (1966-1980), contains material on the meetings of the Board of Trustees and its subcommittees: the International, Executive, Finance, and Communications Committees. Of particular interest are Bell's rough notes summarizing the meetings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The folders are arranged chronologically by date of meeting. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order. Files of the Board of Trustees meetings on a given date precede those of the subcommittees.

did.unittitle: Special Board Review Meetings, June - July 1976
International Committee Meeting, Sept. 1976 - Education Paper
Board of Trustees Meeting, India - Oct. 2-6, 1978
Board of Trustees Meeting, Mar. 29-30, 1979 - background material
Board of Trustees Meeting, Mar. 27-28, 1980 - background material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV, Agriculture Files (1966-1979), contains material on the administrative and program development of five international centers for agricultural research and development. It includes extensive material on the meetings of the Consultative Group for International Research (CGIAR), and its Task Force on International Assistance for National Agricultural Research (ISNAR), of the annual International Centers Week, and of the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is divided into the following four sub-series:
A. International Agricultural Center Files (2.5 boxes)
B. CGIAR/ISNAR Files (2 boxes)
C. Agriculture Meeting and Conference Files (1.5 boxes)
D. International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) Files (1 box)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first section of this subseries consists of general material on the administration and program development of five international agricultural centers. The second section of this subseries consists of files on each agricultural center.

c.arrangement:
ArrangementThis sub-series is further divided into two sections. The first section is arranged chronologically. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.
The second section is arranged alphabetically by Ford Foundation program area in effect at that time (A&P, LAC, MEA) and chronologically within each area. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first section of this subseries consists of material on the organization of the Consultative Group for International Agricultural Research (CGIAR) and the procedures of its committee meetings. The second section of this subseries consists of material on the formation and committee meetings of the CGIAR's Task Force on International Assistance for National Agricultural Research (ISNAR).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is further divided into two sections. Within each section, the folders are arranged chronologically. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

did.unittitle: Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research - General
Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first section of this subseries consists of material on the annual meetings of International Centers Week. The second section of this subseries consists of material on Ford and Rockefeller Foundation Conferences on Agriculture and Development.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is further divided into two sections. Within each section, the folders are arranged chronologically. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

did.unittitle: FF/RF Meetings re: Agricultural Institutes, Mar. 10-14, 1969

International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series consists of material on the organization, administration, and periodic meetings of the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This sub-series is arranged in chronological order. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V, Population Files (1966-1981), contains material on the program planning, evaluation, and administration of the Population Program. It includes extensive material on some principal grantee organizations and on Ford and Rockefeller (Bellagio) Conferences on Population and Development.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is divided into the following two sub-series:
A. Ford Foundation Population Program Files (2 boxes)
B. Meetings and Conferences (1 box)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first section of this subseries consists of material on the program planning, administration, and evaluation of the Population Program. The second section of this subseries consists of files on grantee organizations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is further divided into two sections. The first section is arranged chronologically. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order. The second section is arranged alphabetically. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

did.unittitle: International Centre for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Bangladesh (ICDDRB)
United Nations Fund for Population Activities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first section of this subseries consists of material on Population Conferences funded by the Ford Foundation. The second section of this subseries consists of material on the Bellagio Population Conferences funded by the Rockefeller Foundation, attended by Mr. Bell and to which he contributed papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is further divided into two sections. Within each section, the folders are arranged chronologically. Within each folder, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI, Subject Files (1966-1981), contains material on selected Foundation procedures, divisions and offices of the Foundation other than the Office of the Vice President/International Division, selected subject areas in which grants were made, selected surveys and studies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series consists of material on selected subject areas in which grants were made, divisions of the Foundation other than the OVP/ID, internal Foundation procedures, selected surveys and studies. It is arranged alphabetically. Within each file, the correspondence is arranged in reverse chronological order.
